Cattle are ruminants, meaning their digestive system is highly specialized to allow the use of poorly digestible plants as food. Cattle have one stomach with four compartments, the rumen, reticulum, omasum, and abomasum. As with other ruminants, they are even-toed ungulates.

Cattle are the most common type of large domesticated ungulates. They are a prominent modern member of the subfamily Bovinae, are the most widespread species of the genus Bos, and are most commonly classified collectively as Bos taurus.

Cattle are ruminants, or cud-chewing mammals. The cows' stomachs have four compartments: the rumen, reticulum, omasum and abomasum. For cows, good quality hay or pasture is the best source of roughage.
